1.0   EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



1.1   INTRODUCTION 

Calpine Corporation operates the Calpine Pittsburg Power Plant (CPPP), a nominal 70-megawatt, gas-fired cogeneration facility located in Pittsburg, California.  CPPP uses anhydrous ammonia as a necessary part of reducing the emissions of nitrogen oxides to the atmosphere. Storing a large quantity of ammonia can be a hazard if it is not handled properly.  Calpine Corporation takes its safety obligations in storing and using ammonia as seriously as we take controlling emissions from the power plant. The following document describes what could happen if there were to be an accident, the steps we take every day to ensure a safely operating plant, and what to do in the event of an emergency. 



1.2   ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Calpine Corporation recognizes the responsibility to make our environment, the community, and employee safety a primary part of our daily concerns.  Calpine Corporation is committed to being a responsible member of any community in which it has operations by giving top priority to operating in a safe and environmentally sound manner.  Calpine is dedicated to developing an environmentally responsible energy resource compatible with community needs. Calpine aims to protect and conserve California?s valuable air and water resources, while providing a reliable source of low-cost electricity for residents and businesses.  Calpine is committed to working closely with community members, environmental groups, and local governmental agencies to meet its obligation to the community and to the environment.  

It is the policy of Calpine Corporation that every employee is entitled to a safe and healthful place in which to work and live.  Calpine?s Operations and Maintenance Department incorporates the concepts of environmental responsibility and productivity with safety, resulting in efficiency and productivity.

As part of its obligation to protect the integrity of human, en

vironmental, physical, and financial resources, and to conserve and efficiently utilize those resources, Calpine will:

* Fully comply with laws regulating Environmental Protection and Employee Health and Safety;

* Furnish workplaces free of recognized hazards likely to cause injury to employees, the public, or the environment;

* Train employees in safe and environmentally conscious practices and require compliance with environmental, health, and safety (EHS) regulations, policies, and procedures; and

* Provide professional staff to maintain and support EHS programs.

Calpine Corporation and CPPP are committed to conducting safe and environmentally sound operations. This commitment is documented in the corporate policy and in the EHS program that is available to all employees at the site.  This program consists of a series of policies, procedures, and manuals for the equipment and chemicals on site. Calpine Corporation has issued a series of EHS guidance procedures for their facilities. The environmental, health and safety program at CPPP includes this RMP and the anhydrous ammonia system manual. The Plant verifies and improves its safety and environmental programs through the Management of Change (MOC) process discussed in Section 1.4.11.

Calpine stresses safety and environmentally sound operations in its written documentation and training courses.  Calpine has trained all of its personnel to be capable of operating the Plant in a safe manner under any condition, including implementing proper emergency response procedures. 

All manuals and procedures are available to employees at all times. The EHS program includes the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Risk Management Program (RMP) and the anhydrous ammonia manual that covers the anhydrous ammonia system. The EHS program includes a Process Safety Management (PSM) program, a Response Contingency Plan, an RMP, guidelines for use of personal protective equipment (PPE), and training requirements an

ironmental Protection Agency (USEPA)/American National Standards Institute (ANSI) limit of filling tanks to 85 percent capacity at 25 degrees Fahrenheit]. Table 1-1 provides program applicability of the covered process. Figure 1-1 shows a simplified process flow diagram.  

Refrigerant-grade anhydrous ammonia is delivered to the Plant by truck and loaded into the holding tank, T-2. Ammonia is vaporized by heaters H-2A and H-2B to maintain pressure in T-2. The vaporizers are located underneath the T-2 ammonia tank and each vaporizer has four heating elements. The suction line to the vaporizers is at the bottom of T-2 and the return line is located at the top of T-2. There are pressure switches on the vaporizer return line that turn on and off each heater. In addition, there are pressure and temperature switches on each heater that provide override protection in case the heaters are blocked in and turned on.  

Ammonia vapor is discharged from T-2 to the ammonia injection skids. The pressurized ammonia vapor from T-2 is reduced to 80 pounds per square inch gage (psig) by a regulator. This pressure drop helps to create a few degrees of superheat in the ammonia vapor to keep it from condensing. It also acts as a pressure step down for the regulator at the ammonia skid to improve flow control. Steam tracing is provided along the ammonia line from the regulator to the skid to ensure that the ammonia in the line always stays vaporized. 

The major components of the injection skid include blowers C1/2/3-A/B for the turbine units and blowers 103/104 for the auxiliary boiler, a flow control meter and valve, a mixing tee, a static mixer, and an injection grid. The blowers provide the air that is to be mixed with the ammonia prior to injection into the Heat Recovery Steam Generator (HRSG). The mass flow meter is located on the ammonia injection skid to measure ammonia flow to the unit. This signal goes to the flow controller algorithm in a Tri-sen fuel controller for the units

and to the Allen Bradley controller for the auxiliary boiler. A flow control valve controls the ammonia flow. An automatic block valve is located downstream of the control valve. Both valves are operated by the Tri-sen fuel control for the units and by the Allen Bradley controller for the auxiliary boiler. A mixing tee is provided where the ammonia is injected into the blower air stream. A static mixer is located downstream of the mixing tee to ensure that the ammonia and air are completely mixed.  

The injection grid consists of twelve 2-inch stainless-steel pipes located upstream of the low-pressure steam section. The 12 pipes are split into six pairs. Each pair has an adjusting valve and differential pressure meter. The adjusting valves have been adjusted to compensate for any distribution problems encountered in the SCR system. The injection grid is located upstream of the low-pressure steam section to allow for additional mixing of the flue gas and the ammonia. The ammonia is compatible with the carbon steel piping of the low-pressure steam section.  

At the injection skid, the ammonia flow rate is adjusted to achieve the desired nitrogen oxide (NOx) emission set point. The ammonia is then mixed with blower-supplied air. The ammonia/air mixture is injected into the HRSG upstream of the low-pressure steam section for the units and into a mixing box prior to the catalyst bed for the auxiliary boiler. Turbine exhaust gas that has bypassed the HRSG by going through the bypass duct enters the HRSG downstream of the low-pressure steam section and is mixed with ammonia-laden HRSG flue gas. Combined exhaust streams enter the catalyst bed where the ammonia is deposited on the catalyst. NOx in the flue gas reacts with ammonia on the catalyst surface to form water and nitrogen. A Continuous Emission Monitor (CEM) measures the NOx level of the flue gas leaving the catalyst. This measurement is used by the Tri-sen to adjust the ammonia injection rate and also for reports

to the Bay Area Air Quality Management District.

Process safeguards include pressure safety valves (PSVs), excess flow valves, emergency shutoff valves and hydrostatic relief valves. There are three sets of PSVs in the SCR system. Each set includes two PSVs and a Transflo valve that ensures one PSV is in service at a time. Two PSVs are on T-2 (PSV R-1 and PSV R-2), two on H-2A (PSV R-3 and PSV R-4), and two on H-2B (PSV R-5 and PSV R-6).  

Emergency shutoff valves are provided on the liquid fill line from the truck to the tank (V9-02) and on the vapor return line from the tank to the truck (V9-09).  The valves can be operated either at the valves or at a distance of about 50 feet from the tank. Closing the valve remotely is done by pulling a cable that causes the valve to shut.  

Hydrostatic relief valves are installed to prevent excessive buildup of pressure in a liquid line that is blocked in.  The two hydrostatic relief valves (HSVs) in the SCR process are located in the line connecting the T-2 vapor outlet to the process and in the liquid fill line.

Excess flow valves (EFVs) are installed in the vapor return line to the tank truck (EFV1: V9-06), the suction line to the vaporizers (EFV3: V9-48), and the ammonia distribution line to the SRC (EFV2: V9-33). The excess flow valves will shut off if the differential pressure across the valves exceeds the rating. The valve will stay shut as long as the differential pressure is maintained.

1.3.3 Characteristics and Hazards of Anhydrous Ammonia

The characteristics and hazards of anhydrous ammonia are included in the Off-Site Consequence Analysis section (Section 2.0) of this document.



1.4   SUMMARY OF THE ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



1.4.1   Management System

CPPP management has developed a formal management system to plan, organize, implement, and control the RMP elements of the anhydrous ammonia system.  This system is based on the following regulations and in

he anticipated operating conditions. In the event the ammonia supply system is not available due to a maintenance activity, a procedure for supplying ammonia directly from the truck is provided as a temporary operating procedure.

Modifications to Operating Procedures

If operating procedures require changing because of a modification to the process, they must be updated and recertified in accordance with management of change (MOC) procedures.  Changes that may require updating of operating procedures include changes in process chemicals, changes in process technology, and equipment and facility changes.  See Section 1.4.11.

If the operating procedures must be modified, the Plant Manager or designee will be responsible for modifying the procedure.  The Plant Manager will review the draft-revised procedures and sign the approval page.  The Plant Manager will forward the revised procedures to the appropriate plant staff for approval and signature. The Plant Manager or designee must update all copies of the operating procedures. 

After completing this review, the Plant Manager will certify each operating procedure as accurate and reflective of current operating practice.  The date that the procedures were modified will be listed on the first page of each operating procedure.  A memorandum should be prepared summarizing who reviewed and modified the procedures, the dates the work was done, who reviewed the revisions, the rationale for the changes, and the date the revised procedures were approved by the Plant Manager.

If any operations or maintenance staff member believes that the operating procedures should be modified to improve system safety and reliability that person should notify their supervisor, who will determine if the procedures should be modified and, if modification is required, initiate the procedures previously described to modify the operating procedures.

The RMP and CalARP regulations require that operating procedures be certified annually to ensure

of the inspection or test performed, results of inspection or test, measures taken to correct any deficiency and the date.

Procedure Revisions.  Maintenance procedures are updated when technicians determine additional maintenance tasks should be implemented.  New maintenance procedures are written, approved by the Maintenance Manager and entered into Maximo. The Plant Engineer is responsible for evaluating whether a proposed change meets the definition of change under PSM/RMP regulations and triggers MOC requirements.

Recordkeeping.  Preventive maintenance records are maintained on file for review as needed.  CPPP maintains records of all critical equipment maintenance activities and maintenance schedules, including inspection and testing activities, for the life of each process.  Maintenance records are completed by maintenance personnel and include the following as applicable:

* Equipment name and reference number

* Date and description of maintenance activity

* Name and signature of person performing maintenance activity

* Name of procedure followed

* Results of maintenance activity and minimum criteria for acceptability

* Summary of actions required to correct any deficiencies

Quality Assurance. The Maintenance Manager will control quality assurance for spare parts and replacement equipment.  The maintenance personnel will order only replacement parts specified by the original manufacturer or that meet the specifications contained on the process drawings and in the equipment files.  All maintenance personnel are responsible for verifying replacement part numbers, ratings, and materials of construction against manufacturer procedures and equipment specifications.  The replacement part, manufacturer, and/or specifications cannot be substituted without approval by the Maintenance Manager who is required to evaluate whether any suggested change of an equipment part or manufacturer still satisfies the original equipment specifications and does not constitute

1.4.3   Record and Document Management

For the Management Program, the Plant Manager is responsible for maintaining annual and monthly schedules and any reports (e.g., procedure checklists, incident investigations) generated from operations personnel activities.  These documents are filed in the Building #631 Power Plant Library.  The Plant Manager has overall responsibility for ensuring that all forms, descriptions, and regulatory information are kept current.  A copy of the PSM documentation is available to all personnel in the Building #631 Power Plant Library.

This management system satisfies the requirements of Section 2735.6 of the CalARP regulation and ensures that the RMP elements are developed and continually improved.  All records associated with the prevention program elements are retained for a minimum of 5 years unless otherwise specified in the CalARP regulation or other applicable regulation.

1.4.4   Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The prevention programs described in this section represent integrated administrative controls intended to ensure the safety of workers, the public, and the environment.  Many of these prevention programs (e.g., PHAs, compliance audits, and incident investigation) result in the development and implementation of additional safeguards (administrative and engineering controls).  Those recommendations that are planned for implementation at CPPP will be discussed in the Planned Changes to Improve Safety section (Section 1.8) of this document.  Those applic

able safeguards that have already been implemented or that were part of the original design are described below.  These safeguards prevent, detect, or mitigate accidental releases of regulated substances.

The covered process has a control system designed to maintain operating parameters (e.g., temperature, pressures, flow, and level) within allowable limits.  The covered process is also equipped with alarms to alert personnel when the operating parameters exceed the allowable limits.  The Plant developed procedures and conducts training of personnel to familiarize them with the consequences of exceeding allowable limits (safety and operability) to ensure the correct response to the alarms.  Table 1-2 lists safeguards of the system.



1.4.5   Prevention Program Elements

DEC?s accidental release prevention program is based on the following key elements:

* Detailed management system and clear levels of responsibilities and team member roles

* Comprehensive safety process information that is readily available to staff, emergency responders, and contractors

* Comprehensive preventive maintenance program

* A process hazard analysis of equipment and procedures with operation and maintenance staff participation

* Use of state-of-the-art process and safety equipment

* Use of accurate and effective operating procedures, written with operations and maintenance staff participation

* High level of training of operators and maintenance staff

* Implementation of an incident investigation, inspection, and auditing program using qualified staff



1.4.6   Process Safety Information

Process safety information (PSI) development, dissemination, and use is vital to the effective operation of a stationary source.  Personnel use information regarding chemical hazards, equipment specifications, and operating limits in daily and strategic decision-making.  Accurate and complete information that is readily accessible to personnel is, therefore, a basic component of the prevention

program.

Established procedures ensured that the original PSI was compiled prior to the original PHAs conducted in 1997.  Dow Chemical, the previous owner of the Plant, developed the original PSI.  The PSI was approved by Contra Costa County Health Services Department (CCCHSD) prior to the beginning of Plant operations.  The PSI is maintained current via the MOC and pre-startup safety review (PSSR) programs.  These programs ensure that the process equipment complies with recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices.

Hard copies of all PSIs are maintained in the Building #631 Power Plant Library.  An electronic copy of much of the information is also available.  Personnel have access to the Power Plant Library, the control room, and the electronic copies on 24-hour basis.  An accurate and current PSI is maintained for the life of the facility and the Plant Manager is responsible for this maintenance.

CPPP compiled PSI to satisfy the regulatory requirements of Section 2760.1 of the CalARP regulations, and to enable personnel (e.g., owner, operator, employees involved in operating the process) to identify and understand the hazards posed by those processes involving anhydrous ammonia.  The following PSI is particularly important to the prevention program:

* Information pertaining to the hazards of the regulated substances in the process.  The following information is available in the MSDS maintained for ammonia:  toxicity information, permissible exposure limits, physical data, reactivity data, corrosivity data, and thermal and chemical stability data.

* Information pertaining to the technology of the process.  The following information is available in the Anhydrous Ammonia System binder:  a process flow diagram for the process and the process chemistry, a table including safe upper and lower parameter limits (e.g., temperature, pressure), and an evaluation of the consequences of deviations from those parameter limits.

* Information pertaining to

the equipment in the process.  The following information is maintained in the Anhydrous Ammonia System binder:  accurate or redlined P&IDs and a table listing the various safety systems (e.g., alarms, shutdowns, materials of construction, relief system) for the process.

Table 1-3 presents the PSI in tabular format.



1.4.7   Process Hazard Analysis

By systematically examining each process and identifying hazards associated with the operation of a covered process, CPPP has been able to plan and take appropriate action to improve the safety of our employees, the community, and the environment.  The Plant facility, under ownership of Dow, performed a PHA on the ammonia storage vessel with the objectives of: 

* Identifying hazards;

* Identifying credible human errors and/or equipment failures that could lead to any accidental release;

* Evaluating the likelihood and/or consequence of various scenarios;

* Determining if existing chemical-specific prevention steps/controls were adequate; and 

* Where existing controls were inadequate, identifying additional steps that could be taken to control the hazard.

In accordance with Section 2760 of the CalARP regulations, the Plant consulted with CCCHSD and determined that the Hazard and Operability Study (HAZOP) methodology was the approach best-suited for the PHA of the ammonia storage vessel.  This methodology was chosen due to the relatively complex design of the ammonia storage and transfer system, as well as the facility?s belief that HAZOPs provide a high level of detail for analysis of this system.  The HAZOP methodology, in addition to all other policies, procedures and operations, was adopted by Calpine upon acquisition of CPPP. 

A HAZOP study is a simple, structured methodology for hazard identification.  It is an investigation technique that is designed to inspire imaginative thinking (or brainstorming) by a team of experts to identify hazards and operational problems while examining a process or system in a

thorough and systematic manner.  A PHA applying a HAZOP involves a systematic, methodical examination of design documents that describe the facility.  The HAZOP is performed by a multidisciplinary team, which identifies safety hazards or operability problems by evaluating deviations from design intents.

The PHA team comprised people with varied operational and technical backgrounds.  At least one team member had knowledge of the standards, codes, specifications, and regulations applicable to the process.  

The team members chosen provided the team with expertise in areas such as process technology, process design, operating procedures and practices, alarms, emergency procedures, instrumentation, maintenance procedures, safety and health, and other relevant subjects.  A similar team will conduct a revalidation of the PHA every 5 years, and update the PHA as necessary, in conjunction with the RMP updates. A revalidation of the PHA was performed in July 2007.

Recommendations or action items identified during a PHA are documented and resolved through the application of MOC procedures.  The MOC procedures are also used to revalidate and update the PHA procedures.  Currently, there have been no changes as a result of the PHA process.  In February 2003, Calpine installed an auxiliary boiler at CPPP.  MOC procedures were used to determine that there are no significant changes to the PHA procedures as a result of the boiler installation.  Other than the addition of the boiler, the ammonia process is the same as was established previous to startup.

A Security Vulnerability Assessment was conducted on May 26, 2005. The method used for the SVA was from the Synthetic Organic Chemical Manufactures Association, Inc. (SOCMA) and was entitled Manual on Chemical Site Security Vulnerability Analysis Methodology and Model.

A copy of the RMP*Submit Data Fact Sheet provides a general overview of the major hazards considered.  The detailed HAZOP study is maintained at the Plant in t

he Building #631 Power Plant Library with the PSM program. 

Section 2755.2 of the CalARP regulations requires the consideration of applicable seismic events, as part of the PHA process. The seismic assessment is conducted by a Professional Civil/Structural Engineer licensed in the state of California.  During the assessment, the engineer will conduct a Plant walkthrough inspection and seismic assessment.  If Plant personnel notice areas of structural concern, the Professional Engineer will be called upon to perform a more detailed seismic assessment.

The Plant seismic performance objective is to maintain structural integrity during and after a seismic event.  This is accomplished by providing positive anchorage of the source and ensuring that there are no major internal source failures.

The Plant is located in a seismically active area of Northern California.  The known significant active faults and seismic sources within 50 miles of the site include the San Andreas, Hayward, Green-Valley-Concord, Calveras, Healdsburg-Rodgers Creek faults, and the Coastal Ranges-Sierra Block boundary zone.  The distance from the fault to the Plant and the maximum expected magnitude are presented in Table 1-4.

Recommendations of a geotechnical consultant were followed in the design of the Plant.  A summary of the specific geotechnical hazards and any expected impacts are presented below (Table 1-5):

Design practices utilize the most recent revisions of the Uniform Building Code (UBC) and related ANSI, ASME, AISC, ACI, and AISI codes, where applicable.  The 1994 UBC was used for defining the minimum seismic

loads for structures, non-building structures and equipment, as well as overall design for normal design loads.

Calpine maintains the integrity of structural components by implementing the established inspection and maintenance procedures and conducting visual walkthrough inspections.  The inspection and maintenance procedures and the objective of each one are listed in Table 1-6.  The visual inspections are performed regularly and include the inspection of all structural components of the Plant.  Attention is paid to components suspended above the ammonia process as well as the process components themselves.

On March 4, 2009, an updated seismic assessment was performed which included the structural aspects of the anhydrous ammonia storage and delivery system. The final report dated April 16, 2009, is included in Section 6 of the Process Safety Management Plan (PSM) binder. 



1.4.8   Operating Procedures

CPPP maintains up-to-date, accurate, written operating procedures that give clear instructions for the ammonia process. Effective operating procedures, when combined with operator training, are instrumental in ensuring safe operation of the systems and preventing accidental releases.  The procedures are developed from equipment manuals and the experience of the operations and maintenance staff. Procedures include startup, shutdown, normal operations, temporary operations, abnormal conditions, emergency operations, and emergency shutdown.  The operating procedures also include safe work practices for hazardous material handling.  All operating procedures are maintained in electronic format in the Plant?s ?electronic library? and hard copies are available by printing the electronic versions.  The operating procedures and safe work practices are kept in electronic form as living documents that are maintained current and accurate through the MOC process.  The MOC process also manages temporary operating procedures. Normal and emergency operating procedures cover t

that the procedures are current and accurate.  The Plant Manager will designate a member of the Operations Staff who will periodically review and update all operating procedures to confirm that they are current and accurate. It is recommended that the following procedures be followed to certify the operating procedures:

1.    Demonstrate and Observe Operating Procedures.  A staff member responsible for RMP management should observe an operator executing all operating procedures. The staff member should use the plant?s existing written operating procedures to check off each step as the operator is performing the procedures. If the actual procedure can not be performed, the operator should verbally describe to the observer the procedures that would be followed to allow the observer to check the procedures.

2.    Address Deviations.  The observer should note any deviations from the written operating procedures and ask the operator to discuss the reason for the deviations. If the deviation is not justified, training or some other type of instruction should be given to all operators to ensure that the specific existing written procedures are followed in the future. If the deviation appears justified, then all Management of Change Procedures should be followed to assure considerations regarding the deviation such as impacts on safety, training, and process safety information are addressed. If all Management of Change Procedures are satisfied then the written operating procedures should be revised to reflect the deviation or change in procedures.

3.    Procedures to be Certified.  All of the applicable operating procedures are certified including the following:

* Initial startup

* Normal operations

* Temporary operations

* Emergency shutdown and operations

* Normal shutdown

* Startup following a turnaround or after an emergency shutdown

4.    Related Procedures.  The following elements relating to the operating procedures are also to be certified that they are current and a

ccurate. See 40 CFR 68.69 (a) (2 - 4) and 19 CCR Section 2760.3(c) for more details:

* Operating limits

* Safety and health considerations

* Safety systems and their functions

5.    Documentation.  To document that certification has been done and each of the elements described in items one through four have been addressed, it is recommended that the annual certification form be completed. This form, like all RMP records, must be kept on file for at least five years. It is not necessary to make a submittal to EPA regarding the certification. However, during the certification process it may be discovered that other elements of the RMP require updating and when some of these elements are updated a submittal must be made to EPA. A submittal is required to EPA if:

* A new regulated substance is added.

* A change is made that requires a revised Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) or hazard review.

* A change is made that requires the offsite consequence analysis to be revised.

* If the program level of a process changes

* If the process is no longer subject to the RMP regulations



1.4.9   Training

Each CPPP employee presently involved in operating or maintaining the ammonia process is trained in an overview of the process and applicable operating and maintenance procedures.  Training helps employees understand the nature and cause of problems arising from operations involving ammonia, and increases employee awareness of hazards.  CPPP?s training program includes both initial and annual refresher training that covers:  (1) a general overview of the processes, (2) the properties and hazards of the substances in the process, and (3) a detailed review of the process operating procedures and safe work practices. Refresher training is conducted at least every 3 years.  Oral reviews and written examinations are used to verify that an employee understands the training material before the process work can be resumed.

Training also is conducted on new and revised operating proc

edures in accordance with the operating procedures and MOC protocols. Training is initiated as a result of a MOC or pre-startup review.

The Plant Manager or designee has overall responsibility for developing and maintaining the written employee training program and associated training materials and training records.

The Plant Manager and Compliance Manager are responsible for ensuring that all required personnel at the facility complete and maintain all job specific and safety/environmental training requirements for his or her position and that all training records are maintained and filed in the respective employee central files in the Administration Building.  

Training records include:  date of most recent review or revision to the training program, type of training required and the type of competency testing used to ensure staff understands the training.  Ongoing employee training records are maintained.  

CPPP developed a written training program to provide employees (those involved with operating the process) with an understanding of the types and causes of potential incidents or deviations within the process, and the hazards associated with the process.  The training program also instructs personnel how to operate the process within safe operating limits and how to handle potential emergencies.  The training program satisfies the requirements of Section 2760.4 of the CalARP regulation and comprises the following:

* Initial employee training;

* Existing employee certification;

* Training provided as a result of an MOC or PSSR;

* Refresher training; and

* Training documentation.

All operators receive initial training in safe work practices and basic operating principles prior to assignment.  The operators receive training specific to the operations of each process once they are assigned to a process.  The training criteria are documented in job dimension documents that list the knowledge required (e.g., safe operating limits, safety system set points)

and skills to demonstrate comprehension (e.g., emergency shutdown, lockout/tagout procedures).  Various means are used to verify competency, including written and oral examinations, demonstrations, and on-the-job training.  Documentation of the training is filed and tracked.  The files include job dimension documents and certification letters of all employees involved in operating the process before June 1999.

Refresher training on specific operating procedures (e.g., normal operations, startup, shutdown), safe work practices (e.g., limiting contractor access, lockout/tagout), and company-wide practices is conducted during the monthly safety meetings, special training classes, and drills.  The current schedule was developed with employee consultation and allows refresher training to be conducted at least every 3 years.  Training documentation (e.g., meeting minutes, attendees, instructor, refresher content, and means used to verify competency) is filed and tracked.



1.4.10   Mechanical Integrity

CPPP maintains the mechanical integrity of process equipment to help prevent equipment failures that could endanger workers, the public, or the environment.  Calpine believes that this program is the primary line of defense against a release.  Maintenance Staff address equipment testing and inspection, preventative maintenance schedules, and personnel training of these procedures.  The site maintenance program includes the following:

* Written procedures for maintaining mechanical integrity through inspection and testing of process equipment, based on instructions of equipment vendors, industry codes, and prior operating experience

* Implementation of written procedures by performing inspections and tests on process equipment at specified intervals

* Training of maintenance personnel in safe work practices such as lockout/tagout, line or equipment opening, and avoidance and correction of unsafe conditions

* Procedures specifying training requirements for contract ma

intenance employees, as well as requiring contractors to use plant-developed maintenance procedures for process areas

The following ammonia equipment is included in the maintenance program: 

* Ammonia unloading station

* Ammonia storage tank

* Ammonia vaporizer

* Ammonia injection grid

* Process piping 

* Controls  

CPPP staff will use a computerized facility asset management program by the name of Maximo.  Maximo is a proven software program that will assist staff by managing the corrective, preventive, and predictive maintenance tasks at our facility. It also provides inventory control and asset cost analysis for the plant and its systems. 

Typically, most corrective maintenance tasks will be generated in the form of a work request generated by the shift operators. The Maintenance Manager will review the work requests daily for validity and authorize a work order. Each work order is sequentially numbered by the Maximo system. These work orders will be stored electronically in the Maximo program to be completed by the Maintenance Department as schedule permits.

Preventive and predictive maintenance tasks will be generated automatically in the form of work orders from the Maximo program. These tasks will also be stored electronically in the Maximo program to be completed by the Maintenance Department as schedule permits. The preventive and predictive maintenance tasks will be developed utilizing equipment vendor recommended and best maintenance practices techniques. Maintenance procedures will be reviewed periodically by the Maintenance Manager or designee to evaluate whether the procedures need to be modified.

Maintenance tasks include inspecting pump bearings, calibrating meter, gauges, and transmitters annually, visually inspecting control valves, cleaning strainers, and checking piping for leaks.  Structural components are inspected by using an anhydrous ammonia maintenance checklist.

The current maintenance tasks will be updated as necessary to inco

rporate any new equipment and processes.

Preventive Maintenance.  Visual inspections (two per 12-hour shift) are the main maintenance tool. Adjustments are made based upon inspection findings.  The following table lists the preventive maintenance tasks for the anhydrous ammonia system at CPPP.  Inspections and tests are described later.

The facility also follows an established list of shutdown check points (piece of equipment is in parentheses), which are listed below:

* Clean all ammonia injection nozzles (ammonia  injection system)

* Calibrate zero-point and span with standard gas (analyzer)

* Calibrate (transmitter)

* Take off dust on catalyst (reactor)

In any case where ammonia must be purged from the system, the facility has a set of established guidelines. The guidelines involve preventing ammonia from venting to the atmosphere, ascertaining that chilled ammonia liquid is no longer in the system, and using experienced personnel.

Inspections and Tests.  Inspections and tests of ammonia process related equipment is performed in accordance with recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices. The use of manufacturer?s recommendations and prior operating experience is paramount in ensuring safe operation and reliability of plant equipment. The inspections and tests shall be performed as follows:

The ammonia process equipment uses threaded joints, gaskets, and ?0? rings. These are subjected to vibration and thermal stresses. The possibility of leaks developing over a period of time is always present. Thorough inspections for leaks are conducted frequently. Any leaks that pose a safety threat, are repaired immediately.  The following general practices are used for very small leaks of anhydrous ammonia:

* Use water-soaked towels to contain small leaks

* Use WD-40 on packless valves and cycle the valve to help stop the leak

* To stop a leak on the level gauge gasket, loosen one screw, add some penetrating oil and tighten.  Oil the screw 180 de

grees opposite.  Then oil the remaining screws. 

* Hydrostatic relief valves have screwed fittings to allow a valve to be screwed in to isolate a leak until repairs can be made.

When a large leak is discovered, CPPP personnel do not attempt to repair the leak.  Instead, the following procedures are followed:

* All personnel are evacuated from the area. The fire department is called and the Emergency Action Plan (Section 1.7) is followed.

* If shutoff can be safely performed, the Main Gas Supply Valve(s) is (are) shut off at the NH3 storage tank. Leaks will stop when all gas downstream of the gas supply valve(s) has been exhausted.

* No repairs are attempted until all anhydrous ammonia gas has dispersed.

Routine visual inspections are conducted at CPPP. The following locations are inspected:

2 times per shift:

* Inspect all pipes, fittings, and tanks for corrosion, leakage.  Confirm relief valves and hose connection caps are in place.

Weekly:

* Inspect blower filters.  Change as required.

Monthly:

* SCR system - efficiency check: flue gas temperature, NOx concentration, ammonia flow, flue gas flow, and slip.

* Ammonia delivery truck hose ? the ammonia supplier performs a monthly inspection on the hose to detect weaknesses in a hose or coupling assembly. 

Annually:

* Blower motor and fan bearings

* Safety valves

* Ammonia injection nozzles 

During Outage:

* Ammonia  injection nozzles ? for deformation or corrosion

Equipment testing is performed in conjunction with the above inspection schedule. If inspection findings warrant testing (e.g., excessive duct, motor or fan vibration), specific tests are performed in accordance with industry standards.

Each inspection resulting in maintenance activities that is performed on the process equipment is documented via the Maximo program. The information provided includes the date, the name of the person who performed the inspection or test, the serial number or other identifier of the equipment, description

a change under the management of change procedure.  Any suggested substitution that constitutes a change will first be subject to the management of change procedure described in Section 1.4.11.  Spare parts are stored in original containers until ready for use.

For new capital construction projects, the facility must ensure that equipment, as it is fabricated, is acceptable for the process application in which it will be used.  This includes a review of acceptable operating ranges (e.g., pressure, temperature, etc.) materials of construction, and any applicable codes or standards.  The facility will perform inspections of new equipment to verify proper installation and consistency with all design specifications.

Upon identification of an equipment deficiency, the affected part and/or system is placed in a safe condition by such means as isolation, venting and draining in accordance with the Lock-Out Tag-Out procedures, and then initiating a work order in the Maximo program.  The work order will alert the Maintenance Manger that an equipment deficiency exists and requires attention. The Maintenance personnel will then follow safe work practices to correct the deficiency.  



1.4.11   Management of Change

This section provides a system for the proper management of changes and modifications to equipment, procedures, chemicals, and processing conditions.  Effective management will help minimize the chance for an accidental release.  A system that manages changes made to the ammonia process will allow changes to be identified and reviewed before they are implemented to determine if the proposed change would compromise system safety.

CPPP staff will conduct a management of change (MOC) review for any temporary change or permanent change, other than replacement-in-kind, affecting the anhydrous ammonia process. The site will utilize the MOC procedures defined in PAP-04, Management of Change. A copy of PAP-04, Management of Change is included in Appendix F.

Change is

defined as all modifications pertaining to any one or more of the following:

* Procedures

* Technology (i.e., processing conditions)

* Equipment

* Facility (i.e., building, fire protection, services, etc.)

* Chemicals used in the process

* Other changes at the plant that may impact a covered process

MOC procedures are not required to be implemented for ?Replacements in kind.?  A replacement in kind is defined as a replacement that satisfies the original design specifications, such as replacing a relief valve with the same kind of relief valve.  However, replacement of a piece of equipment that is substantially different such as replacing one brand with another brand would not be considered a replacement in kind since the equipment design is likely different enough to warrant a review of the change.

If a change in process equipment covered under RMP/PSM is made, its effects must be addressed, employees informed, and the written procedures updated.  The intent is to require management of all modifications to equipment, procedures, and processing conditions other than ?replacement in kind? by identifying and reviewing them before implementing them.  Minimum requirements for management of change include the following:

* Establishing written procedures to manage change

* Addressing the technical basis, effects on safety and health, and required authorizations for the change

* Informing and training employees affected by the change

* Specifying the time period for the change

* Requiring authorization for the proposed change

* Updating process safety information and operating procedures or practices

Responsibilities.  All operators and maintenance personnel are responsible for understanding what a change is and shall not make a change without first implementing this MOC procedure.  If operations and maintenance personnel are uncertain if a replacement is a change, they must consult with the Maintenance Manager for instruction before proceeding.

The Plant En

gineer ensures that all operations and maintenance personnel are aware and apply the MOC procedure, including completing the MOC form whenever a system or process change needs to be conducted onsite.  

The  Plant Engineer  and Compliance Manager shall ensure that all operators and maintenance personnel receive MOC training (as part of initial training) prior to being qualified to complete MOC forms.  See Section 9 of the PSM Plan binder, "Training," for further details.

The Maintenance Manager is responsible for procuring replacements which are the same manufacturer and model number as the original manufacturer parts or thoroughly reviewing substitutes to ensure that they comply with the original design specifications and design intent.  See Section 8 of the PSM Plan binder, "Mechanical Integrity," for further details

The  Plant Engineer is responsible for reviewing MOC forms, evaluating if a proposed change deviates from original system design specifications and determining whether it is a change.  If a MOC is required then the Plant Engineer and Compliance Manager shall arrange for a PHA review of the change.  See Section 1 of the PSM Plan binder, "Process Hazard Analysis," for further details.

Management of Change Procedures.  The Plant Engineer is responsible for evaluating whether a proposed change meets the definition of change under PSM/RMP regulations and triggers MOC requirements.  The MOC Form must be completed and submitted to Plant Manager for authorization prior to implementing a change.  Information required on the Management of Change Form includes the following:

* Information about the change

* Originator

* Date of origin

* Proposed date of change

* Permanent or temporary change (If temporary, how long will the it be in effect?)

* Description and location of change 

* Technical basis for change (Is change required to improve process, reliability, or safety?) Additional justification for change, such as a manufacturer?s recommendation, shou

ld be attached to the form.

* Impact to safety and health

* Change in design criteria (If change will result in a change to the original system design criteria, this should be documented along with calculations justifying the revised design criteria.  Design criteria do not include chemical usage, equipment sizing, or frequency of operation.)

* Type of change

* Indicate the type of change as shown

For the pre-modification checklist, indicate before the modification is made whether the following items are applicable for the change:

* Consult P&IDs and specifications

* Comply with accepted engineering practices

* Comply with environmental protection guidelines for operations

* Comply with safety requirements 

* Consult maintenance 

* Consult instrument or electrical technician 

* Evaluate and modify relief system (if necessary)

* Complete required reviews (pre-startup checklist)

* Other

Before startup, verify that the following items on the post-modification checklist have been completed:

* Performed pre-startup review

* Completed or updated training program

* Wrote job procedures and obtained approval for them

* Updated P&IDs process flow sheets and plot plans

* Trained personnel on the change

* Updated PSM with new process safety management changes

* Updated PSM with new operating procedures or practices

* Updated preventative maintenance procedures

The originator signs and dates the process change checklist and submits it to the Plant Engineer for review and approval.  The Plant Engineer will then review the description of the proposed change and associated hazards to ensure all original system design specifications are satisfied and overall process safety is unaffected prior to providing authorization to proceed with the proposed change.

In the case of an Emergency, the Operator will secure the Ammonia system.  A work order will be written to repair the case of the emergency.  If a change to the process needs to be done to correct the prob

lem, the MOC procedure will be followed.

Process Hazard Analysis  If a proposed change significantly affects overall process safety or the results of any previously conducted PHA, a PHA will be performed or updated in accordance with the PHA procedure in Section 1.4.7.

Examples of changes that could significantly affect process safety include the following:

* Increasing chemical storage or delivery capacity or new regulated chemical;

* Modifying piping and valve arrangements that can affect how systems can be blocked in, bypassed, or vented in an emergency;

* Changing materials of construction or applying a specification different from the original specifications;

* Modifying control logic, set points (outside of approved ranges or design limits), interlocks, or alarm points;

* Changing process conditions (i.e., flow, temperature, and pressure outside of previous normal operating range); and

* Plant changes that can move fire or impact hazard or adversely affect existing safety systems.

All hazard analysis recommendations will be addressed prior to providing authorization to proceed with the proposed change.  Updating the hazard analysis will require updating the RMP/PSM documentation.

If the change requires the PSI to be updated, a PSSR must be completed and documented in accordance with procedures detailed in Section 1.4.12, Pre-startup Safety Review.

Contract employees who may be affected by the ammonia process are advised of the MOC procedure during on-site contractor orientation.

Recordkeeping Requirements  The process change checklist form and any other documentation supporting the change such as information supporting the technical basis for the change should be maintained by the Plant Engineer.

All staff impacted by the change must be trained regarding the change.  Training records must be maintained as described in Section 1.4.9, Training.



1.4.12   Pre-Startup Safety Review

A PSSR is to be performed for new facilities and for modified facil

ities when the modification is significant enough to require a change in the PSI.  The review ensures that adequate safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and that the operators are trained in the procedures before starting the equipment/process.  For new facilities, recommendations from the PHA must be resolved or implemented before initial operation.  At CPPP, this section applies to any changes in or nearby the ammonia tank or system or that might affect the ammonia alarm system.

A PSSR was done in June 1998 when Calpine acquired the Plant.  Initially, the ammonia tank system was started up and subsequently each individual skid unit was started up.  During this startup process, a PSSR was conducted prior to startup of each portion of the unit.  The purpose of PSSRs is to ensure that certain important considerations (such as safety measures) have been addressed before ammonia is introduced into a process at the Plant, or before modified Plant processes involving ammonia are restarted.

Calpine?s written PSSR procedure and checklist satisfy the requirements of Section 2760.7 of the CalARP regulation.

New Facilities

The PSSR for new facilities will be conducted as outlined below:

* All written PSI will be compiled, including information concerning the hazards of ammonia, the technology of the processes involving ammonia, and the equipment involved in the processes.  This information will be available to all personnel involved with processes regarding ammonia.

* Information regarding project construction and process equipment (e.g., construction codes and standards, and revision numbers or dates) will be reviewed to confirm that all construction and equipment is in accordance with design specifications.  Certification to this effect will be made by the Plant Engineer and will be maintained in the appropriate engineering or plant files within his/her office.

* All safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures will be rev

iewed to confirm that they are written, implemented, and adequate.  These procedures will be available to all personnel involved with processes regarding ammonia.

* A PHA will be performed in compliance with the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.119 (e).  This analysis will be available to all personnel involved with processes regarding ammonia, and will be retained for the life of the process.  In addition, all recommendations from the PHA will be resolved or implemented prior to startup.

* Training of each employee involved with processes involving ammonia will be completed prior to startup.

To verify completion of the activities discussed above, a PSSR verification document will be completed and signed by the Plant Manager.  Completed verification documentation will be maintained in the Plant Engineer?s office, central files, and/or the Building #631 Power Plant Library.

When PSSRs are completed, the startup of new or modified equipment involved in the ammonia refrigeration system will be conducted in accordance with applicable industry standards, manufacturers? recommendations, and/or Plant procedures.

Modified Facilities  The PSSR for modified facilities will be conducted as outlined below, when modifications are significant enough to require a change in the PSI.

* All written PSI will be compiled or updated, including information concerning the hazards of ammonia, the technology of the processes involving ammonia, and the equipment involved in the processes.  This information will be available to all personnel involved with ammonia processes.  

* Information regarding project construction and process equipment (e.g., construction codes and standards, and revision numbers or dates) will be reviewed to confirm that all construction and equipment is in accordance with design specifications.  Certification to this effect will be made by the Plant Engineer and maintained in the appropriate engineering or plant files within his/her office.

* All safety, operating,

maintenance, and emergency procedures will be reviewed to confirm that they are written, implemented, and adequate.  These procedures will be available to all personnel involved with processes regarding ammonia.

* The requirements for MOC as required by 29 CFR 1910.119 (l)) will be completed prior to startup (see MOC, Section 1.4.11 of this RMP).

* Initial and refresher training of each employee involved with processes involving ammonia will be completed prior to startup (see Training, Section 1.4.9 of this RMP).

To verify completion of the activities discussed above, a PSSR verification document will be completed and signed by the Plant Manager.  Completed verification documentation will be maintained in the Plant Engineer?s office.  When PSSRs are completed, the Plant Manager will give authorization to appropriate personnel to initiate startup of the Plant.  The startup of all new or modified equipment involved in the ammonia process will be conducted in accordance with applicable industry standards, manufacturers? recommendations, and/or Plant procedures.



1.4.13   Compliance Audits

Internal compliance audits are conducted every three years to verify compliance with the programs and procedures contained in the RMP. The Compliance Manager will assemble a team that includes at least one person knowledgeable in the ammonia process and an audit leader knowledgeable in RMP requirements and audit techniques. A person is considered knowledgeable if they have operated or maintained the ammonia process for more than one year or have prepared RMPs for ammonia systems. An outside consultant or an internal team may be used to perform the compliance audit.

The audit team evaluates whether the prevention program satisfies the requirements of the RMP rule and whether the prevention program is sufficient to help ensure safe operation.   A series of questions on a Compliance Audit Questionnaire will be answered by conducting equipment inspections, record reviews and inter

views. 

The audit team will summarize the results of the compliance audit in a Compliance Audit Report of Findings.  The report will record RMP program deficiencies identified by the team, the corrective actions to be taken, the staff assigned to implement the corrective actions, and the target completion date.  All identified corrective actions will be assigned by the Plant Manager to the appropriate staff for follow-up.  MOC procedures will be followed before corrective action is taken.  

It will be the responsibility of the Compliance Manager to ensure all audit corrective actions are resolved or implemented in a timely manner and the resolution thoroughly documented.  The documentation is required to include a summary of the corrective action taken, the staff member implementing the action, and the date completed.  Whenever a corrective action is not implemented, a written explanation will be prepared explaining why the action is no longer appropriate or no longer applicable.

The last Compliance Audit was performed on January 20, 2009.



1.4.14   Incident Investigation

Each incident that resulted in or could reasonably have resulted in a catastrophic release of anhydrous ammonia must be investigated.  The site shall utilize incident investigation procedures as defined in SHP-9, Injury Management. The purpose of this section is to summarize the process described in SHP-9 that will be used to identify the underlying causes of incidents and implement procedures to prevent similar events from occurring in the future. The incident investigation procedure covers the RMP regulated process (anhydrous ammonia) at CPPP.  This procedure applies to all incidents that result in or could have resulted in a catastrophic releases.  A catastrophic release is defined as a major uncontrolled emission, fire, or explosion involving one or more regulated substances that presents imminent and substantial endangerment to public health and the environment or presents serious danger

to employees at CPPP.  Calpine?s policy is to go further and investigate all reportable releases as well.

Incident Investigation Team.  The Plant Manager and/or Compliance Manager shall determine the members of the Incident Investigation Team, if it is determined a formal investigation is required.  The investigation team may include:

* A Department Manager

* The Compliance Manager

* Employee(s) familiar with the operations and/or mechanics of the system or equipment

* A member of the contractor?s staff if the incident involved a contract employee

* A member of the Contra Costa Fire Department and/or a member the CCCHSD HazMat/CalARP team for a catastrophic release, if appropriate

Other members may be assigned to the Incident Investigation Team as deemed appropriate.

Investigation Process.  The investigation process is initiated with the report of the incident to the Plant Manager by the staff involved in the incident.  

The Plant Manager and Maintenance Manager should be notified of the incident immediately after it occurs. Refer to the Internal Notification Chart located in the EAP for additional notifications.  When appropriate emergency response actions have stabilized the situation and conditions onsite are safe, the Plant Manager shall begin the investigation and serve as the leader of the investigation.  The investigation must begin within 48 hours after the incident occurred.  The Investigation Team, as a group, will investigate the incident by:

* Interviewing staff involved in the incident

* Interviewing other staff who have knowledge about the process that may be helpful in the investigation

* Checking records such as alarm printouts

* Discussing the incident as a group

* Physically examining the process

* Calpine has compiled a series of questions to help the investigation team identify some of the less obvious ways of preventing incidents. These questions may include: 

WHAT equipment failed?

* How can we prevent failure or make it less

likely?

* How can we detect approaching failure?

* How can we detect failure when it occurs?

* How can we mitigate the consequences of failure?

WHICH behavior failed? (Consider behavior of those who could operate, manage, supervise, train, check, and design better.)

* What did we fail to do?

* How can we prevent failure or make it less likely? (Consider training, instructions, checking, etc.)

WHICH material leaked, reacted, or exploded?

* What is the function of the material

* What material could we use instead?

As part of the incident review, human error that may have contributed to the incidents will also be reviewed.  Such error will be classified as follows:

* Failure to perform a required function

* Performed required function out of step

* Performed an unnecessary function

* Failure to recognize a hazardous condition requiring correction

* Inadequate or inappropriate response to a contingency

* A wrong decision to solve a problem

* Poor timing

A determination will be made as to whether the error can be corrected by instituting general or specific safeguards for the process, or whether it is necessary to institute additional training for the employees.

Incident Investigation Report.  The Incident Investigation Team prepares a report on the incident.  The standard report form will be used and supplemented as needed.   The report form includes date and time of the incident, date investigation began, description of the incident, contributing factors, corrective actions (recommendations), conclusions, incident investigation team members, and date the incident report was completed. 

Recommendations resulting from the investigation report will then be assigned by the Plant Manager to the appropriate staff (operations, maintenance, or engineering personnel) for prompt follow-up.  Recommendations often require additional evaluation to determine if they are technically and/or economically feasible; therefore, the Plant Manager shall also list the tar

get evaluation date, resolution and resolution date for each recommendation. It is the responsibility of the Plant Manager to ensure that all recommendations are properly resolved and documented in the incident investigation report.  Whenever a recommendation is not implemented, a written explanation of its exclusion shall be documented.  

The incident investigation report shall not be considered complete until all recommendations are resolved and documented.  

When the report is complete, the report shall be reviewed and signed by all incident investigation team members. The Plant Manager will be responsible for designating a staff member to review the incident investigation report and any changes resulting from the report with all staff members who operate and maintain the applicable system. All staff members who could be affected by the changes will also be given a copy of the report.  In addition, incident investigation findings will be communicated to all contract employees if relevant to their job tasks.  The findings of the report will also be communicated to CCCHSD, the public and other stationary sources as applicable.

All changes that are implemented must be reviewed in accordance with the MOC procedures.  Following these procedures will help to identify changes that will affect other sections of the plan.

In addition to the Incident Investigation process defined in SHP-9, procedures for documenting the resolutions and corrective actions of incident report findings are described in SHP-2, Safety Communications. 

Recordkeeping.  All signed incident investigation reports and attendance sheets collected for those informed of investigation results shall be retained by the Compliance Manager for a minimum of 5 years.

1.4.16   Hot Work Permit

PSM and CalARP regulations require employees and contractors to employ safe work practices when performing ?hot work? in, on, or around the anhydrous ammonia process.  To ensure that hot work is done safely, a hot work permit program must be developed that requires that a permit be issued before hot work is performed.  The site shall utilize hot work permit procedures as defined in SHP-11, Hot Work. The purpose of this section is to summarize the process described in SHP-11 that will be used for hot work permitting at CPPP.  The Hot Work Permit Program has been written  to provide accountability and documentation necessary for ensuring the safe performance of hot work during normal operations, maintenance and construction operations. Hot work permits document that the fire prevention and protection requirements in 29 CFR 1910.252(a) have been implemented prior to beginning the hot work operations.  The hot work permits program also applies to any contractor work conducted at this facility.  

The fire prevention and protect

ion requirements contained in the fire prevention and suppression procedures and hot work permit assist in accidental release prevention by requiring proper equipment is utilized, that flammable and combustible materials are not present when hot work is performed, the training of staff performing hot work, the positioning of staff to watch for fires or sparks from hot work, and for strictly controlling activities that may cause sparks or fire.  More specific fire prevention precautions are provided in the Hot Work Permit.

The  Plant Manager is responsible for the overall administration of the Hot Work Program.  Under the direction of the  Plant Manager, the on shift Operator is responsible to conduct required inspections to ensure that all hot work in conducted safely, and for issuance of the Hot Work Permit.  The Maintenance Manager is responsible to ensure that all maintenance department personnel shall strictly adhere to the requirements of this procedure.

The Hot Work Permit Program includes procedures for storage and use of cylinders, fire prevention and suppression, electric welding, cutting and heating procedures, ground returns and machine grounding, welding cables and connectors, manual electrode holders, and procedures for the removal of combustibles.  The hot work permit includes date and time of hot work, location of hot work, persons performing the hot work, description of the hot work, results of atmosphere testing, and a checklist to make sure that precautions have been taken. Hot Work Permits must document that the fire prevention and protection requirements have been implemented prior to beginning the hot work and are valid for a maximum of 12 hours.

Firewatchers shall be trained in the use of fire extinguishing equipment.  They shall be familiar with facilities for sounding an alarm in the event of a fire.  They shall watch for fires in all exposed areas, try to extinguish them only when obviously within the capacity of the equipment available,

or otherwise sound the alarm.  A fire watch shall be maintained for at least ? hour after completion of welding or cutting operations to detect and extinguish smoldering fires. In addition, the employee responsible for authorizing the hot work shall inspect the area at least once per shift while the hot work permit is in effect.

A Hot work permit shall be cancelled when:

* Work has been completed

* When circumstances would make the continued use of the ignition source hazardous;

* Any time the conditions of the issued hot work permit changes;

* Inactivity of permitted hot work in excess of two (2) hours unless test(s) determine the LEL is less than 0%.

* When a hazardous situation develops

* At the end of workers shift (no more than 12 hours)

All hot work permits will be maintained on file in the Building #631 Power Plant Library for a minimum period of 5 years following completion of the hot work.

The program is also important to release prevention because it requires contractor briefings, access controls, and evaluation, all activities which control the actions of contractors while they work on or near the ammonia process.

1.5   THE 5-YEAR HISTORY

Section 2750.9 of the CalARP regulations require reporting the five-year accident history of the covered processes. The details of accidental releases are required for accidents that have caused at least one of the following:

* Onsite deaths, injuries, or significant property damage.

* Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place.

CPPP has had no accidents involving anhydrous ammonia in the past five years.  



1.6   THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

CPPP has an established stand-alone written emergency action program that is followed by employees to help safely control accidental releases of hazardous substances. PSM and RMP regulations require that an Emergency Action Plan be prepared for facilities th

at are not responding facilities. The plan must be prepared in accordance with the provisions of 8 CCR 3220, Emergency Action Plan. Calpine has developed specific emergency response procedures to minimize the effects of accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia on employees, the public, and the environment.

The Emergency Action Plan described in this section is for facilities whose employees are not responders to emergency situations. In the event of an accidental release that requires mitigation by emergency response personnel, the Contra Costa County Hazardous Materials Department will be the primary response agency for CPPP. Because Calpine is located within the Dow Chemical facility, arrangements are in place so that Dow Chemical Emergency Responders will also respond and provide additional support as needed. 

CPPP is manned by a single operator during normal and off business hours. As part of the normal operator rounds of the facility, the anhydrous ammonia process is inspected twice per operating shift or four times per day. If during the inspection or any other time a leak is identified or reported, the operator is expected to assess the extent of the leak and to take the appropriate measures. Incidental leaks that can be isolated and repaired shall be promptly addressed and only performed provided it is safe to do so. Major leaks or releases that require emergency response shall require initiation of the Anhydrous Ammonia Response Procedure and Power Plant Evacuation Procedure as defined in the Emergency Action Plan. The on-shift operator will assume the responsibilities of the emergency response official in charge of the site-specific Incident Command System (ICS) until relieved by the Plant Manager. Upon arrival of the Contra Costa County Fire Protection Department or County HAZMAT team, the highest ranking official will then assume this position. All emergency responders and their communications are coordinated and controlled through the Incident Commander (IC). 

The IC should identify, to the extent possible, all hazardous substances or conditions present and address maximum exposure limits of the released chemical, hazardous-substance handling procedures, and use of any methods used to control leaks. The Contra Costa County Hazardous Materials Area Plan provides procedures for initiating the Community Warning System (CWS). The CWS sirens will be requested by the IC or unified command, through consultation with the Hazardous Materials Incident Response Team.
